explanation: This genotype is associated with lower lactase enzyme activity in adulthood, meaning you may have more difficulty digesting regular dairy products without symptoms like bloating or discomfort.
This genotype is associated with continued lactase production into adulthood, so you are more likely to tolerate regular dairy compared to CC carriers, though individual tolerance can still vary.
This genotype is strongly associated with lactase persistence, meaning you are more likely to digest dairy products well into adulthood.
This genotype is associated with higher CYP1A2 enzyme activity, meaning your body tends to clear caffeine more quickly than average, so its effects may wear off sooner.
This genotype is associated with somewhat slower caffeine metabolism than AA, so caffeine may stay in your system longer and have stronger or longer-lasting effects.
This genotype is associated with reduced CYP1A2 activity, meaning your body may break down caffeine more slowly, so smaller amounts can feel stronger or last longer.

This genotype is associated with the presence of functional α-actinin-3 protein in fast-twitch muscle fibers and is more common in strength and power athletes, although training and lifestyle still have a major influence.
This genotype is associated with an intermediate pattern of α-actinin-3 expression and is often seen as a mix between power and endurance tendencies, with training strongly shaping performance.

This genotype leads to a lack of α-actinin-3 in fast-twitch fibers and is somewhat more common in endurance-oriented athletes, though overall fitness still depends heavily on training, health, and environment.
This genotype is associated with typical MTHFR enzyme activity, so folate processing is generally similar to the population average. Diet and overall health still matter more than genetics alone.
This genotype is associated with moderately reduced MTHFR enzyme activity compared with CC. Some studies link it to slightly higher homocysteine levels, but lifestyle and nutrition play a major role.

This genotype is associated with lower MTHFR enzyme activity and a stronger tendency toward higher homocysteine in some studies. This does not diagnose any condition, but it highlights the importance of adequate folate intake and general cardiovascular health.
This genotype is associated with typical ALDH2 enzyme activity, so there is less tendency toward facial flushing from small amounts of alcohol, although individual sensitivity still varies.

This genotype is associated with reduced ALDH2 activity and a higher chance of facial flushing, nausea or discomfort even with modest alcohol intake. It is also linked with higher acetaldehyde buildup, so minimizing alcohol use is especially important.

This genotype is associated with very low ALDH2 activity and a strong tendency to flush and feel unwell with alcohol. This is informational only and not medical advice, but it supports being very cautious with drinking.
This genotype is associated with typical FADS1 activity, meaning your body’s conversion of plant-based omega-3s into long-chain forms like EPA and DHA is closer to average.

This genotype is associated with somewhat lower FADS1 activity, which may mean a modestly reduced ability to convert plant omega-3s into long-chain forms. Food choices still have a much larger impact than genetics alone.

This genotype is associated with lower FADS1 activity and a tendency toward lower levels of some long-chain omega-3 fatty acids. This does not diagnose any condition but can support paying extra attention to dietary sources of EPA and DHA.

This genotype is considered a typical pattern for the COL5A1 variant, with no strong signal toward either stiffer or more flexible tendon properties. Training load and technique are far more important for injury risk.
Some studies suggest this genotype may be linked to subtle differences in tendon or ligament properties. Any effect is likely small compared with training, recovery, and biomechanics.

This genotype has been associated in some research with different collagen characteristics, which may slightly change how tissues respond to load. This information is exploratory and should not be used to predict or diagnose injury.

This genotype has been associated in some studies with a somewhat stronger improvement in aerobic capacity from endurance training. Training quality and consistency remain the main drivers of performance.
This genotype may be linked to an intermediate pattern of endurance adaptations, with genetics playing only a small role beside training, nutrition, and recovery.
Some research suggests this genotype may show slightly smaller VO₂max gains, but exercise habits, coaching, and health easily outweigh these subtle genetic effects.
This genotype is associated with typical AMPD1 enzyme function, so your muscle response and recovery from intense bursts of exercise are likely similar to the general population.

effect_label: Higher fatigue tendency in intense efforts
explanation: This genotype has been linked to reduced AMPD1 activity in some studies and may be associated with feeling fatigue sooner during very intense exercise, though results are mixed and training adaptation is key.

effect_label: More pronounced altered muscle metabolism tendency
explanation: This genotype can lead to much lower AMPD1 activity and has been associated with different muscle energy use during intense effort. This is informational only and not a diagnosis; many carriers still perform at very high levels.
This genotype has been associated with a tendency toward slightly longer usual sleep duration in some studies. The effect is small, and schedule, stress, and habits matter far more.
With one A and one G allele, your natural sleep duration tendency may fall between the two extremes, but real-life sleep patterns are mostly shaped by lifestyle, environment, and mental health.
This genotype has been associated with somewhat shorter habitual sleep duration on average. This does not mean you must sleep less; good sleep hygiene can strongly influence your actual sleep time.
This genotype is generally associated with a more typical FKBP5-related stress response. Life experiences, coping skills, and environment have a much larger influence than genetics alone.

This genotype has been linked to somewhat different regulation of the HPA axis in some studies, which may translate into a tendency toward stronger or more prolonged stress responses in certain situations.

This genotype has been associated with greater FKBP5 expression changes and altered feedback in the stress system. This does not predict any mental health condition but highlights the value of healthy coping strategies and support.
This genotype is strongly associated with being able to taste certain bitter compounds (like PTC/PROP) more intensely, which may also influence how some vegetables and bitter foods taste.
This genotype is usually linked with moderate sensitivity to these bitter compounds, so some foods may taste somewhat bitter without being extremely intense.
This genotype is associated with a reduced ability to taste certain bitter compounds, so some people experience these foods as milder or less bitter overall.

effect_label: Strong tendency toward blue or light eyes
explanation: This genotype is a major genetic predictor of blue or lighter eye colors, although other pigmentation genes and family background can still modify the final shade.
This genotype is often associated with intermediate or variable eye colors, such as hazel or green, depending on other pigmentation variants and ancestry.

effect_label: Strong tendency toward brown or darker eyes
explanation: This genotype is strongly associated with brown or darker eye colors, although other genes can still influence the exact shade.
This genotype is not strongly linked to the classic red-hair MC1R variant, so your sun sensitivity is more likely to follow your overall skin type and sun exposure habits.
Carriers of one copy of this MC1R variant may have lighter pigmentation, more freckles, and a greater tendency to burn rather than tan, though daily sun protection is important for everyone.

Two copies of this MC1R variant are often associated with red or reddish hair, fair skin, and a strong tendency to burn easily. This is not a diagnosis, but it supports being especially careful with sun protection.
